column6: title=Cesare De Titta – Dedicato al poeta abruzzese}}</ref><ref>Francesco Piga ''La poesia dialettale del Novecento'', Piccin Vallardi, 1991, pag. 61</ref>

column1: His mother was Sofia Loreto, and his father, Vincenzo De Titta, was a public notary. Cesare attended the Seminary of [[Lanciano]] since he was sixteen to become a priest and studied classical languages at the Seminary of [[Venosa]] from [[1881]] to [[1889]], where he would be later its dean. Among his most important linguistic works, we find ''Grammatica della lingua viva'' and ''Grammatica della lingua latina''.<ref>{{Cite web

'''RLSY College, Paliganj''' also known as '''Ram Lakhan Singh Yadav College, Paliganj''' is a degree college in [[Patna district]] of [[Bihar]], [[India]]. It is affiliated with [[Patliputra University]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=5 April 2020}}</ref> The college offers [[senior secondary education]] and [[undergraduate degree]]s in arts, science and conducts some vocational courses.

column3: 350px]]The college was established in 1985 by [[Ram Lakhan Singh Yadav]]. It got affiliation with [[Patliputra University]] in 2018.

column1: The college offers the following degrees and courses.

'''Charles Foley''' (1908 – 1995)<ref name=\"NLA\">[https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/21717245?q&versionId=26095636 Charles Foley's profile at the National Library of Australia]</ref> was an Indian-born British journalist.

Foley was born in India in 1908 and began working as a journalist in Paris on the ''Paris Herald,'' a European edition of the ''[[New York Herald]]'' now known as the ''[[International Herald Tribune]]''. From 1940 to 1955 he served as Foreign Editor on the British newspaper ''[[The Daily Express]]''.  In 1954 he interviewed Hitler's former commando chief, [[Otto Skorzeny]] – then living in Madrid. Foley subsequently wrote ''Commando Extraordinary, Otto Skorzeny'' (Longman Green, London, 1954), a well-crafted but laudatory account of Skorzeny's war-time exploits.

In 1955 Foley moved to [[Cyprus]] and took over ''[[The Cyprus Times]]'' newspaper at a moment in the islands history when a civil war was breaking out between Greek and Turkish Cypriots, and the Greek Cypriot [[EOKA]] movement was starting an armed struggle against the British colonial government in Cyprus.<ref>'The Press: Tough Times' in ''Time Magazine,'' 15 September 1958.</ref> He later published a number of books on Cyprus.
*''The struggle for Cyprus'' [together with W. I. Scobie] (Stanford, Calif.: Hoover Institution Press, 1975).
He also published ''The memoirs of General Grivas'' (London: Longmans, 1964), approved by the military leader of EOKA, [[Georgios Grivas]].

In 1955 Foley moved to [[Cyprus]] and took over ''[[The Cyprus Times]]'' newspaper at a moment in the islands history when a civil war was breaking out between Greek and Turkish Cypriots, and the Greek Cypriot [[EOKA]] movement was starting an armed struggle against the British colonial government in Cyprus.<ref>'The Press: Tough Times' in ''Time Magazine,'' 15 September 1958.</ref> He later published a number of books on Cyprus.
*''The struggle for Cyprus'' [together with W. I. Scobie] (Stanford, Calif.: Hoover Institution Press, 1975).
He also published ''The memoirs of General Grivas'' (London: Longmans, 1964), approved by the military leader of EOKA, [[Georgios Grivas]].

column1: →‎top:Update date format tag and add authority control template,safe,Rich Farmbrough,"{{short description
'''John (Jack) Renton''', also known as \"The White Headhunter\"<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=The White Headhunter: The Story of a 19th-Century Sailor Who Survived a South Seas Heart of Darkness
column7: isbn=0786712562}}</ref>, was a Scottish seaman from [[Orkney]] who was shipwrecked in 1868 and landed at Maana'oba Island in the [[Solomon Islands]]. He became a slave of a bigman named Kabbou for 8 years, in which he learnt the Lau language, participated in the island's culture, and became a [[headhunting
column8: headhunter]]. He is the only European to have been a headhunter and was the first European to live for a long period on [[Malaita]]<ref>{{cite web
column13: accessdate=11 April 2020}}</ref>. After being rescued by a [[Royal Navy]] ship in 1875, he returned to Orkney, but at some point he became disillusioned with life in Europe and tried to return to Malaita, but was killed in 1878 at Aoba Island. Upon learning of his death, Kabbou and the people of the village Jack had lived in mourned his death by sacrificing 300 pigs in his name, telling tales of his life for 3 days straight, and building a reliquary house which acted as a shrine to his memory. The shrine survived for 85 years until it burned down in 1963.

Upon learning of his death, Kabbou and the people of the village Jack had lived in mourned his death by sacrificing 300 pigs in his name, telling tales of his life for 3 days straight, and building a reliquary house which acted as a shrine to his memory. The shrine survived for 85 years until it burned down in 1963.

column1: add authority control,safe,Ser Amantio di Nicolao,"'''Brian D. O'Neill''' is an American author and attorney, best known for ''[[Half a Wing, Three Engines and a Prayer]]'', a book about the U.S. Eighth Air Force and [[B-17]] crews and missions in [[World War II]].  He is also the author of ''303rd Bombardment Group'', about the same subject.

Born into a U.S. Air Force family in 1949, O'Neill's growing up years were spent on many Air Force bases throughout the United States, at a time when piston-engined aircraft a generation or two behind the B-17 were still in wide use.  His Air Force upbringing fostered a lifelong interest in World War II aviation history.  After graduating from the University of Maryland in 1971, O'Neill served with the [[U.S. Navy]] for three years, first as a [[destroyer]] gunnery officer and then as a shipyard repair officer at the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard.  Upon leaving military service he became an [[Attorney at law
column2: attorney]] and the General Counsel of [[Curtiss-Wright Corporation]], the aviation company that had manufactured the P-40 Warhawk fighter and the [[Wright Cyclone series
column3: Cyclone]] B-17 engines during World War II.  In 2001 O'Neill left corporate life to enter the private practice of law.   As of 2013 he manages a very active immigration and employment law firm based in Morristown, New Jersey.<ref>{{cite book
column4: title=Half a Wing, Three Engines and a Prayer

column1: * [[Half a Wing, Three Engines and a Prayer]]. McGraw-Hill Companies, 1999. ISBN .

'''Christopher Trent''' is a British writer and was born in [[Sussex]].
After spending most of his childhood in [[Twickenham]] in the [[UK]] and [[Richmond, London
column2: Richmond]] in the [[UK]]. He received his initial education St Paul's School, and then went onto [[University College, Oxford
column3: University College]] [[Oxford]]. He studied classics, philosophy and archaeology at the City Literary Institute.

column1: After the war, during which he was Deputy Chief Information Officer for the North-West, he then devoted his time to full-time writing and took an interest in the [[Fens]] and [[London]]<ref>From a book called ''The Russells'' published  Muller - No date (Circa 1960s)</ref>

Perhaps one of his best books is ''Motoring Holidays in Britain'' published in 1959 which shows readers many beauty spots reached by unfrequented routes, every one of which has been travelled by the author and illustrated by his own photographs. These routes have stood the test of time and are as enjoyable today as they were 50 years ago, particularly if you own a classic car.
* ''Greater London: Its Growth and Development over 2000 years.''
* ''The Story of England in Brick and Stone''

column1: '''Cénacle''' is the name given to a [[Paris, France
column2: Parisian]] literary group of varying constituency that began about 1826 to gather around [[Charles Nodier]]. The group sought to revive in [[French literature]] the old monarchical spirit, the spirit of medieval mystery and spiritual submission.  The chief members were [[Alfred de Vigny
column4: Deschamps]].  They were soon joined by [[Alphonse de Lamartine
column7: Sainte-Beuve]], who describes the group as \"royalists by birth, Christians by convention and a vague sentimentality.\"  Their organ was ''La Muse Française''. [[Alfred de Musset
column9: Mérimée]], and the elder [[Alexandre Dumas, père
column10: Dumas]] were involved within the Cénacle, too.  Time and the revolution of 1830 wrought changes in the attitudes of the members of Cénacle.  [[Théophile Gautier]] and [[Gérard de Nerval]] were attracted to the group at the time of the revolution, but the reasons for the existence of the Cénacle dissolved. The group lost its reason for existence with the triumph of [[Victor Hugo

column4: title=''L’Âge des cénacles: Confraternités littéraires et artistiques au XIXe siècle'' by Anthony Glinoer, and Vincent Laisney

He practices journalism since the early age of 18. He started as a collaborator in the [[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)
column2: Clarín]] newspaper and in [[Radio Continental]]. In 1983 he was the first reporter of the newscast “Mitre informa primero”. He developed an intensive activity in television, first as a reporter in the news editions of Canal 11- [[Telefé]], covering both local and international events, and later as Executive Producer in Red de Noticias – the 24 hours information channel of Telefé-, in CVN (Cablevisión Noticias) and in the Canal 7 newscasts. Since the year 2002, Frescó had dedicated himself to writing books on journalistic subjects such as the wave of abductions in [[Buenos Aires]] in the late 1990s.

column1: →‎External links:Update date format tag,safe,Rich Farmbrough,"'''Thomas Hill Jamieson''' (1843–1876) was a Scottish librarian.

Jamieson, born in August 1843 at Bonnington, near [[Arbroath]], in Scotland, was educated at the burgh and parochial school of that town, and afterwards (1862) at [[Edinburgh High School]] and University. While still at college he acted as a sub-editor of ''Chambers's Etymological Dictionary,'' and subsequently became assistant to [[Samuel Halkett]], librarian of the [[Advocates' Library]].

In June 1871, on Halkett's death, Jamieson was appointed keeper of the library, and the work of printing the catalogue passed into his care. In 1872 he wrote a prefatory notice for an edition of [[Archie Armstrong]]'s ''Banquet of Jests,'' and in 1874 edited a reprint of Barclay's translation of Brandt's ''Ship of Fools,'' to which he prefixed a notice of [[Sebastian Brandt]] and his writings. In 1874 he also privately printed a ''Notice of the Life and Writings of [[Alexander Barclay]].''

The fire which occurred in the Advocates' Library in the summer of 1875 roused him to exertions beyond his strength, and he died at 7 Gillespie Crescent, [[Edinburgh]], on 9 January 1876, aged only 32. He married, on 11 June 1872, Jane Alison Kilgour, by whom he left two children.
[[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]]","'''Thomas Hill Jamieson''' (1843–1876) was a Scottish librarian.

Jamieson, born in August 1843 at Bonnington, near [[Arbroath]], in Scotland, was educated at the burgh and parochial school of that town, and afterwards (1862) at [[Edinburgh High School]] and University. While still at college he acted as a sub-editor of ''Chambers's Etymological Dictionary,'' and subsequently became assistant to [[Samuel Halkett]], librarian of the [[Advocates' Library]].

In June 1871, on Halkett's death, Jamieson was appointed keeper of the library, and the work of printing the catalogue passed into his care. In 1872 he wrote a prefatory notice for an edition of [[Archie Armstrong]]'s ''Banquet of Jests,'' and in 1874 edited a reprint of Barclay's translation of Brandt's ''Ship of Fools,'' to which he prefixed a notice of [[Sebastian Brandt]] and his writings. In 1874 he also privately printed a ''Notice of the Life and Writings of [[Alexander Barclay]].''

The fire which occurred in the Advocates' Library in the summer of 1875 roused him to exertions beyond his strength, and he died at 7 Gillespie Crescent, [[Edinburgh]], on 9 January 1876, aged only 32. He married, on 11 June 1872, Jane Alison Kilgour, by whom he left two children.
[[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]]",Thomas Hill Jamieson,//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Hill_Jamieson
'''Udayana Warmadewa''', also '''Dharmmodayana Warmadewa''', was a king of the island of [[Bali]] in the 10th century.<ref name=indianized>{{Cite book

column2: title = The Indianized states of Southeast Asia

column3: 129}} He belongs to the [[Warmadewa dynasty]]. He married to the Javanese queen [[Mahendradatta]], also known as Gunapriyadharmapatni. Their son was the famous [[Airlangga]], who replaced the overthrown emperor of Java [[Dharmawangsa]], and ruled in both [[Java]] and his original home of [[Bali]].<ref>Hanna, p.24</ref>

column1: Udayana is known as one of the earliest historical figure of ancient Bali. His identification as the father of the famous [[Airlangga]], the hero-king of Java, has led him to be the prominence figure in Balinese history in par with ancient Java. As the result his name is associated with Balinese past greatness. In 1962 the [[Udayana University]] ({{lang-id
column2: Universitas Udayana}}), a public [[university]] was established in [[Denpasar]], [[Bali]], [[Indonesia]]. The university's name was derived from this king. Also, the [[Indonesian Army]] named their Bali-based [[Indonesian Army
column3: Military Command Region]] (Kodam), in his honor, the [[Kodam IX/Udayana]].

column1: '''Vesturbyggð''' is a [[municipality]] located in the [[Westfjords]] in [[Iceland]].
In Vesturbyggð there is the town [[Patreksfjörður]] with 627 inhabitants, [[Bíldudalur]] with 166 inhabitants and [[Krossholt]] with 19 inhabitants.
The municipality is served by [[Patreksfjörður Airport]] and [[Bíldudalur Airport]].

'''RLSY College, Gaya''' also known as '''Ram Lakhan Singh Yadav College, Gaya''' is a degree college in [[Gaya district]] of [[Bihar]], [[India]].It is an Affiliated College of [[Magadh University]]. The college offers [[senior secondary education]] ,[[undergraduate degree]]s and [[Postgraduate degree]]s in arts, science and conducts some vocational courses.

column3: 350px]]The college was established in 1987 by [[Ram Lakhan Singh Yadav]]. It is an Affiliated College of [[Magadh University]] [[Bodh Gaya]].

column1: The college offers the following degrees and courses.

'''Bill Giant''' (March 2, 1930 – November 26, 1987) was a songwriter whose work included over 40 songs for [[Elvis Presley]].

Giant grew up in [[New York City]] and was known as '''Bill \"Harvey\" Zimmerman'''.  He was part of the popular songwriting team ''Giant, Baum and Kaye'', writing songs with [[Bernie Baum]] and [[Florence Kaye]]. The majority of their work was used in Presley movies, although their most popular recording was \"(You're The) Devil in Disguise\" which reached No.3 on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 and No.1 on the U.K. singles chart in 1963. They were also credited with writing the American version of [[Osamu Tezuka]]'s anime \"[[Kimba the White Lion]]\" (1965).  Giant became a realtor in [[Middlesex County, New Jersey]] in his later years. His other memorable name was '''Billy Merman'''.
His other works include songs in the following films:

column2: Herb Alpert School of Music]], [[University of California, Los Angeles]]<ref name=\"UCLA\">{{Cite web
column5: date=August 5, 2016}}</ref> and also a published author of 10 books, being held in 1,163 libraries, the highest book is in 728 libraries worldwide.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: accessdate=August 5, 2016}}</ref> He has also been active in multimedia development, having received several grants for developing the World Music Navigator, a computerized ethnographic atlas from the early 1990s.<ref name=\"UCLA\"/>

column1: He received both his Bachelor of Arts and also Ph.D. in Anthropology from the [[University of Illinois]]. He has also taught at [[Dartmouth College]] and also [[University of Washington]], where he held the position of Director of the School of Music for years until then becoming the  Director of the [[UCLA School of the Arts and Architecture]] from 1996 to 2002 and then also subsequently holding the position of UCLA's Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost from 2002 to 2006.<ref name=\"UCLA\"/>

The '''Linn County Courthouse''' in [[Mound City, Kansas]] was built in 1885.  It was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1974.
It was designed by Topeka architect [[George Ropes]].  It is a two-story-with-basement red brick building with a {{convert
column9: m}}.  Its foundation is a native [[limestone]] wall, separated from brick above by a smooth cut stone [[belt course]].  A second belt course circles the building at level of the second story's window sills.<ref name=nrhpdoc>{{cite web
column12: title=National Register of Historic Places Inventory/Nomination: Linn City Courthouse

column1: *[[Old Linn County Jail]], also NRHP-listed in Mound City
[[Category:Government buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in Kansas]]

'''''Tritonoturris phaula''''' is a [[species]] of [[sea snail]], a marine [[gastropod]] [[mollusk]] in the [[family (biology)
The length of the shell varies between 7.7 mm (holotype) and 8.7 mm.
This marine species occurs off [[False Bay]], East London, South Africa
* Steyn, D.G. & Lussi, M. (1998) Marine Shells of South Africa. An Illustrated Collector's Guide to Beached Shells. Ekogilde Publishers, Hartebeespoort, South Africa, ii + 264 pp.

(1977) Taxonomic studies on the marine Mollusca of southern Africa and Mozambique. Part 1. Annals of the Natal Museum, 23, 173–214]

column5: title = Catalog of recent and fossil turrids (Mollusca: Gastropoda)

'''Brunslar''' was a short-lived [[municipality]] in North [[Hessen]], in the now-extinct [[Districts of Germany
column2: district]] of [[Melsungen]], [[Germany]]. It was created during the changing of district boundaries on 1 February 1971, when the independent communities of [[Altenbrunslar]] and Neuenbrunslar fused. On the 31. December 1971 the community of [[Wolfershausen]] joined the Brunslar municipality.<ref name=Gemeindeverzeichnis1970bis1982>{{citation
column4: title=Historisches Gemeindeverzeichnis für die Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Namens-, Grenz- und Schlüsselnummernänderungen bei Gemeinden, Kreisen und Regierungsbezirken vom 27. 5. 1970 bis 31. 12. 1982

column1: At the beginning the municipality covered an area of 1271 [[Hectare
column2: ha]], in which approx. 1300 people lived. As the village of Wolfershausen was integrated, the area grew to 1641 ha and the population grew to approx. 2000.

column1: On 1 January 1974 the municipality of Brunslar, together with the municipalities of Gensungen, Helmshausen, Hilgershausen und Rhünda were included into the town of [[Felsberg (Hessen)
'''Brunslar''' was a short-lived [[municipality]] in North [[Hessen]], in the now-extinct [[Districts of Germany
column2: district]] of [[Melsungen]], [[Germany]]. It was created during the changing of district boundaries on 1 February 1971, when the independent communities of [[Altenbrunslar]] and Neuenbrunslar fused. On the 31. December 1971 the community of [[Wolfershausen]] joined the Brunslar municipality.<ref name=Gemeindeverzeichnis1970bis1982>{{citation
column4: title=Historisches Gemeindeverzeichnis für die Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Namens-, Grenz- und Schlüsselnummernänderungen bei Gemeinden, Kreisen und Regierungsbezirken vom 27. 5. 1970 bis 31. 12. 1982

column1: At the beginning the municipality covered an area of 1271 [[Hectare

ce,safe,Viriditas,"'''Jim M. Bowler''' is an Australian geologist known for discovering the [[Lake Mungo remains]], which are considered the oldest human remains in Australia.<ref>McGregor, Lisa (14 Feb 2018). [https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-02-12/mungo-man-what-to-do-next-with-australias-oldest-remains/9371038 “Mungo Man: What to do next with Australia's oldest human remains?“] ''ABC News''. Retrieved 12 April 2020.</ref> He is a professorial fellow at the [[University of Melbourne]], School of Earth Sciences.

Bowler made his discovery in western New South Wales in March of 1969.<ref>Bowler, J. (2003). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/24054272 ‘Tribal loyalties': reconnecting with the land. A tribute to Mrs Alice Kelly, 1919–2003]. ''Aboriginal History'', 27, 247–248.</ref>  At the time, Bowler was in the department of biogeography and geomorphology at the [[Australian National University]].  The human remains he found, and their subsequent radiocarbon dating, contributed to the historical rewriting of the timeline for Aboriginal settlement.<ref> Foster, S. G., & Varghese, M. M. (2009). ''[https://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt24hdt9 The Making of The Australian National University: 1946-1996]''. ANU Press. pp. 241-242.</ref> The human remains Bowler found near Lake Mungo date to approximately 40,000 years ago.

[[Category:Australian National University alumni]]","'''Jim M. Bowler''' is an Australian geologist known for discovering the [[Lake Mungo remains]], which are considered the oldest human remains in Australia.<ref>McGregor, Lisa (14 Feb 2018). [https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-02-12/mungo-man-what-to-do-next-with-australias-oldest-remains/9371038 “Mungo Man: What to do next with Australia's oldest human remains?“] ''ABC News''. Retrieved 12 April 2020.</ref> He is a professorial fellow at the [[University of Melbourne]], School of Earth Sciences.

Bowler made his discovery in western New South Wales in March of 1969.<ref>Bowler, J. (2003). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/24054272 ‘Tribal loyalties': reconnecting with the land A tribute to Mrs Alice uKelly, 1919–2003]. ''Aboriginal History'', 27, 247–248.</ref>  At the time, Bowler was in the department of biogeography and geomorphology at the [[Australian National University]].  The human remains he found, and their subsequent radiocarbon dating, contributed to the historical rewriting of the timeline for Aboriginal settlement.<ref> Foster, S. G., & Varghese, M. M. (2009). ''[https://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt24hdt9 The Making of The Australian National University: 1946-1996]''. ANU Press. pp. 241-242.</ref> The human remains Bowler found near Lake Mungo date to approximately 40,000 years ago.

'''Pusp Jain''' (born 4 April 1956) was a member of the [[13th Lok Sabha]] and [[14th Lok Sabha]] of [[India]]. He represented the [[Pali (Lok Sabha Constituency)
column2: Pali]] constituency of [[Rajasthan]] and is a member of the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] (BJP) political party.<ref>[http://www.rediff.com/news/1998/feb/03raj.htm Many stalwarts, fewer candidates in Rajasthan]</ref><ref>[http://164.100.47.194/Loksabha/Members/MemberBioprofile.aspx?mpsno=160&lastls=14 Fourteenth Lok Sabha]</ref>

column2: Pali]] constituency of [[Rajasthan]] and is a member of the [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] (BJP) political party.<ref>[http://www.rediff.com/news/1998/feb/03raj.htm Many stalwarts, fewer candidates in Rajasthan]</ref><ref>[http://164.100.47.194/Loksabha/Members/MemberBioprofile.aspx?mpsno=160&lastls=14 Fourteenth Lok Sabha]</ref>

column1: '''Alija''' is both a surname and a given name. Notable people with the name include:
*[[Kučuk Alija]] (died 1804), janissary, mutesellim of Kragujevac and one of four Dahiyas who controlled Belgrade Pashaluk
*[[Alija Jussupowa]] (born 1984), rhythmic gymnast of Kazakh ethnicity who competes for Kazakhstan
*[[Alija Behmen]] (1940-2018), former mayor of Sarajevo and a member of the Social Democratic Party of Bosnia and Herzegovina
*[[Alija Bešić]] (born 1975), retired Luxembourgian professional football player of Bosnian descent
*[[Alija Đerđelez]], popular legendary hero of poetry and literature in Bosnia and Albania
*[[Alija Dumas]] (born 1929), former Democratic member of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives
*[[Alija Isaković]] (1932–1997), Bosnian writer, publicist and lexicographer of Bosnian
*[[Alija Izetbegović]] (1925–2003), the first President of Bosnia and Herzegovina
*[[Alija Sirotanović]] (1914–1990), Yugoslav miner of Bosnian Roma ethnicity, Hero of Socialist Labour
*[[Alija Eaglespike]] of ''Warrior'', a fantasy novel written by Australian author Jennifer Fallon
*[[Alija del Infantado]], a municipality which is part of Tierra de La Bañeza comarca, an autonomous community of Castile and León, Spain

column2: the American author Daniel J. Flynn

column1: '''Daniel J. Flynn''' is an American author and [[columnist]].
His most recent book is ''The War on Football: Saving America's Game'' (Regnery, 2013). He wrote a weekly Friday column on [[pop culture]] for''[[The American Spectator]].''
*''A Conservative History of the American Left'' (Random House, 2008)
*''Blue Collar Intellectuals: When the Enlightened and the Everyman Elevated America'' (ISI, 2011)
*''Intellectual Morons: How Ideology Makes Smart People Fall for Stupid Ideas'' (Random House, 2004)
*''Cop Killer: How Mumia Abu-Jamal Conned Millions Into Believing He Was Framed'' (1999)
*''Cult City: Jim Jones, Harvey Milk, and 10 days that shook San Francisco'' (ISI Books 2018)  <ref>{{cite web

column2: the American author Daniel J. Flynn

column1: '''Daniel J. Flynn''' is an American author and [[columnist]].
His most recent book is ''The War on Football: Saving America's Game'' (Regnery, 2013). He wrote a weekly Friday column on [[pop culture]] for''[[The American Spectator]].''
*''A Conservative History of the American Left'' (Random House, 2008)
*''Blue Collar Intellectuals: When the Enlightened and the Everyman Elevated America'' (ISI, 2011)
*''Intellectual Morons: How Ideology Makes Smart People Fall for Stupid Ideas'' (Random House, 2004)
*''Cop Killer: How Mumia Abu-Jamal Conned Millions Into Believing He Was Framed'' (1999)
*''Cult City: Jim Jones, Harvey Milk, and 10 days that shook San Francisco'' (ISI Books 2018)  <ref>{{cite web

The '''UN COVID-19 Supply Task Force''' is a task force set up by the [[United Nations]] to coordinate the procurement and distribution of personal protective equipment, diagnostic tests and oxygen to countries with overstretched healthcare systems.<ref name = who>{{cite news
column2: title=WHO Director-General's opening remarks at the media briefing on COVID-19 - 10 April 2020
column6: title=COVID-19: WHO inaugurates supply chain task force
column10: date=9 April 2020}}</ref> This initiative will be run by the [[World Health Organization]] and the World Food Programme, along with the multiple partners of United Nations.<ref name = who/> The hubs of this supply chain system will be located in China, Belgium, Ethiopia, Panama, Malaysia, Ghana, South Africa and the United Arab Emirates. According to the WHO, the supply chain may need to cover more than 30% of the world's needs in the acute phase of the pandemic. WHO announced that the World Food Programme will need to deploy eight 747 aircraft, eight medium sized cargo aircraft and several smaller passenger planes to move the equipment and staff.<ref name = who/>
